113604 S2468-8231(23)00687-9 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113604 Fig. 1 (a) Furfural oxidation performance over Rux/δ-MnO2, (b) Ru's TOF in Rux/δ-MnO2. (Ru's TOF =nFF in * (Conver. [Rux/δ-MnO2] * Select. - Conver. [δ-MnO2] * Select.)/ nRu / t * 100 %, nFF in represents the furfural feed mole number, nRu represents the mole number of Ru, Conver. [Rux/δ-MnO2] represents the furfural conversion of Rux/δ-MnO2, Conver. [δ-MnO2] represents the furfural conversion of δ-MnO2, Select. represents the furoic acid selectivity, and t represents the reaction time. The above equation describes the magnitude of the gain from the addition of Ru per unit mass). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Furfural in-situ IR for (a) δ-MnO2; (b). Ru0.25/δ-MnO2. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a). The analogy between geminal diol intermediate dehydrogenation and methanol dehydrogenation; (b). Hydrogen production rates of δ-MnO2, Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru1/δ-MnO2 catalysts in the methanol dehydrogenation reaction; (c). CO release rate in the methanol dehydrogenation reaction for δ-MnO2, Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru1/δ-MnO2 catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) XRD pattern of Rux/δ-MnO2, (b) Enlargement of XRD pattern in the 10–30° interval. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TEM images of δ-MnO2 with different Ru loadings. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) H2-TPR spectra of Rux/δ-MnO2, (b) Reduction peaks of RuOx in H2-TPR spectra. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a). XPS Ru 3p spectra of Rux/δ-MnO2, (b) Average oxidation states of Ru in Rux/δ-MnO2. (AOS=4 × a + 6 × b, a, b are the percentages of +4 and +6 valence respectively). Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a). XPS Mn 3 s spectra of Rux/δ-MnO2 (b). XPS O 1 s spectra of Rux/δ-MnO2. Fig 8 Fig. 9 a) O2-TPD spectra of Rux/δ-MnO2; (a). M/Z = 32 (O2) signal, (b). M/Z = 18 (H2O) signal. Fig 9 Fig. 10 The structure evolution of Rux/δ-MnO2 with different Ru loading. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Schematic diagram of the promoting effect of Ru on furoic acid synthesis over Rux/δ-MnO2 catalyst. Fig 11 Fig. 12 Relationship between AOS of Ru and TOF of furfural oxidation. Fig 12 Table 1 Catalytic performance of furfural Oxidation to furoic acid over δ-MnO2 and Ru0.25/δ-MnO2. State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 China δ-MnO2 exhibits excellent activity for furfural oxidation to furoic acid under base-free conditions. However, its poor CH bond breaking capacity leads to lower conversion efficiency per unit mass catalyst than noble metal. Thus, a series of Ru-modified δ-MnO2 (Rux/δ-MnO2) have been made to enhance its CH bond breaking ability. The result showed that the furfural conversion was greatly enhanced on Rux/δ-MnO2 due to the enhanced capability for breaking the CH bond. Especially for Ru0.25/δ-MnO2, whose conversion rate per unit mass was 18 times higher than δ-MnO2. The characterization results showed that the Ru species mainly existed as single atoms or clusters on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru0.5/δ-MnO2, while started to aggregate to RuO2 nanoparticles on Ru1/δ-MnO2 and Ru2/δ-MnO2. With the increase of Ru particles, the Ru's average oxidation state (AOS) decreased from +6 on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 to +4.74 on Ru2/δ-MnO2. The Ru's TOF (intrinsic activity per Ru) was positively linearly related to the Ru's AOS. The electron-deficient Ru in Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can strongly adsorb the H atom of the CH of geminal diol intermediate and accelerate the breakage of its CH bond. As a result, Ru in the Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 exhibited the highest TOF, which can even reach 29.85 mmolFF/mmolRu/h. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Base-free Ru/δ-MnO2 C–H bond breaking Furfural oxidation to furoic acid Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction Biomass is a green and renewable resource that is derived from a wide range of sources, making it a perfect renewable carbon feedstock for energy, chemicals, and materials. The widespread use of bio-chemicals and bio-materials derived from biomass is significant for achieving carbon neutrality. Furoic acid is a high value-added bio-chemical that is widely used in fragrances, pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals [1]. Most importantly, furoic acid can be used for the synthesis of polyester monomer furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which is a green alternative to the widely used terephthalic acid(PTA) [2–6]. Catalytic oxidation of furfural to prepare furoic acid is the greenest and most efficient route [7], noble metal and non-noble metal catalysts have been applied in this technology. The noble metal catalysts primarily consist of Au [8–12], Pt and Pd systems [13–15], which can efficiently convert furfural under low or base-free conditions. While the expensive cost of these catalysts made them inapplicable. The non-noble metal catalysis primarily involves active components such as copper oxide [16] and cobalt [17], which can convert furfural only under high alkali conditions. As a result, a significant amount of acid is needed to neutralize the excess alkali, which is environmentally unfriendly. Thus, it is urgent to develop non-noble and base-free catalysts for furfural oxidation. According to the mechanism of furfural oxidation [2,13,18], three steps are key to furoic acid synthesis: 1) The activation of furfural's aldehyde group to generate geminal diol intermediates; 2) The activation of O2 to generate active oxygen species; 3) The oxidative dehydrogenation of geminal diol through breaking CH bonds to produce furoic acid. Our previous research showed that δ-MnO2 has plentiful inherent hydroxyl groups, which can efficiently attack the aldehyde group of furfural to generate geminal diol intermediates. Moreover, the oxygen species arising from the oxygen activation and the inherent hydroxyl groups are helpful to break CH bond of geminal diol to produce furoic acid [19,20]. These properties of δ-MnO2 help it show similar catalytic performance to noble metals under base-free conditions. While the conversion efficiency per unit mass of the catalyst is still lower than noble metal due to its poor ability to break the CH bond of geminal diol. Thus, great efforts need to be made to increase the conversion efficiency per unit mass of the catalyst of δ-MnO2. For formaldehyde oxidation, it is reported that the breaking of the CH bond is a heat-absorbing process with the highest △E value in the radical reaction step, which is considered to be rate-determining [21]. Considering the similarity of furfural oxidation with formaldehyde oxidation, it is deduced that the breaking of the CH bond of furfural is important for furoic acid synthesis. Thus, it is urgent to enhance the ability to break the CH bond of δ-MnO2 to increase the reaction rate per unit mass of catalyst. Ru can well assist the dehydrogenation process because it has excellent CH bond-breaking ability. Xiao et al. [22]. found for benzyl alcohol oxidative cyanidation reaction, the addition of 0.1 wt% Ru to MnO2 can greatly enhance CH bond breaking ability of Ru/MnO2 catalyst and greatly enhance the generation of the intermediate benzaldehyde. Yamaguchi et al. [23]. found that CH bond breaking was the decisive step in the benzyl alcohol dehydrogenation reaction, and the addition of Ru could substantially improve the reaction activity by enhancing the CH bond breaking ability. In conclusion, the addition of Ru can improve the dehydrogenation activity by enhancing the CH bond-breaking ability. Considering the poor CH bond activation ability of δ-MnO2, it can be deduced that the addition of trace Ru to δ-MnO2 might strongly enhance the CH bond breaking ability of the catalyst, which is helpful for furoic acid synthesis. Based on the above analysis, a series of Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts were prepared in this work. The catalysts were characterized by H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and TEM, the CH bond breaking ability was demonstrated by methanol dehydrogenation probe reaction, and the enhancement of Ru on furfural oxidation to furoic acid was analyzed. Experimental Manganese sulfate monohydrate (MnSO4.H2O), ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4), ruthenium trichloride (RuCl3), ammonium persulfate ((NH4)2S2O8), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), all of the above reagents were purchased at Aladdin. Preparation of mno2 with different crystalline forms The preparation details of δ-MnO2 are as follows: Dissolving 0.676 g MnSO4.H2O and 3.792 g KMnO4 in 140 g deionized water and then heated at 160 °C for 12 h in 200 ml of PTFE liner. The precursor obtained above was filtered and washed, then dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The obtained catalyst was identified as δ-MnO2. The preparation details of Ru/δ-MnO2 are as follows: The above step of drying δ-MnO2 was changed from drying at 80 °C for 12 h to drying at 80 °C for 6 h. Disperse 2 g of the above solid in water, add a certain amount of RuCl3 solution(the mass fraction of Ru is 0.25 wt%, 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 2 wt%) and sonicate for 5 min. RuCl3 was precipitated with a certain concentration of NaOH, stirred at 50 °C until completely dry, and finally dried in an oven at 80 °C for 6 h. The obtained catalysts were noted as Rux/δ-MnO2 (x is the mass percentage of Ru in the catalyst, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, respectively. In particular, x = 0 is noted as δ-MnO2). Evaluation of catalysts The experimental parameters are as follows. Reactor: stainless-steel magnetic stirring batch reactor (100 ml). MaterialS: 50 mg of furfural, 10 ml of deionized water, and 200 mg of catalyst powder. Reaction condition: 1 MPa O2, 100 °C, 1 h, 500 r/min. With further clarifications in the manuscript, the experimental parameters were altered. The products were analyzed by HPLC under the following conditions, detection wavelength=220 nm, mobile phase (acetonitrile: water=1:1), C18 columns. Catalyst characterization See Supporting Information for catalyst characterization details. Results and discussion Performance of furfural oxidation to furoic acid over Rux/δ-MnO2 The synthesized catalysts were tested in the reaction of furfural oxidation to furfural acid(see Fig. 1 a). The δ-MnO2 was able to achieve 50.07 % furfural conversion at 100 °C. While the furfural conversion was greatly enhanced on all Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts. The furfural conversion sharply increased to 78.24 % on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2, which is 27.90 % higher than δ-MnO2. With the continued increase of Ru loading, the furfural conversion slightly increased to 89.34 % on Ru1/δ-MnO2, while decreasing to 81.41 % on Ru2/δ-MnO2. Moreover, the TOF values based on Ru were compared. The result showed that Ru's TOF values on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 were found to be much higher than other catalysts (see Fig. 1b). The reaction condition was further optimized for δ-MnO2 and Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 catalysts, and the evaluation results are shown in Table 1 . As can be seen, a 69.68 % furfural conversion was obtained on δ-MnO2 at 120 °C, 0.2 g Catalyst, 1 h (Entry 2). While Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can achieve 99.55 % furfural conversion under the same reaction condition (Entry 4). Even as the reaction time shorted to 0.5 h, a 99.46 % furfural conversion can still be obtained on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 (Entry 5). While δ-MnO2 can not reach a similar furfural conversion unless the catalyst is increased to 0.3 g and the reaction time is increased to 6 h (Entry 3). That is to reach a similar furfural conversion(99 %), the reaction time and catalyst amount of Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 were only 1/12 and 2/3 compared to δ-MnO2, respectively (Entry 3 and Entry 5). In addition, Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 accomplishes the rapid conversion of furfural to furoic acid, avoiding the deep oxidation of furoic acid for a long time under high-temperature oxygen conditions. To verify the accelerating effect of Ru on the reaction process, δ-MnO2 and Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 were chosen as the representative catalysts to be characterized by the in-situ IR technique. After absorption of furfural, the δ-MnO2 showed the typical IR peaks of furan ring in furfural and geminal diol intermediate at 1390 cm−1 and 1022 cm−1, respectively [24,25] (see Fig. 2 a). After the introduction of O2, the IR peaks at 1022 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1 gradually weakened with time, while the peak at 1542 cm−1 gradually increased, indicating that the conversion of furfural and intermediates to furoic acid. While, after absorption of furfural, the Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 (see Fig. 2b) showed weaker peaks at 1390 cm−1 and 1022 cm−1 but strong peaks at 1542 cm−1, indicating the Ru greatly accelerated the conversion of furfural and geminal diol intermediate to furoic acid. Physical-chemical properties of Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts A series of characterization techniques were carried out to explore the enhancement of Ru on furfural oxidation. The FTIR spectra showed that the Rux/δ-MnO2 exhibited similar hydroxyl groups at 3186 cm−1 and 3557 cm−1 to δ-MnO2(see Fig. s1). Methanol dehydrogenation was used as a probe reaction to characterize the CH bond-breaking capabilities of Rux/δ-MnO2 (see Fig. 3 a). For δ-MnO2, the hydrogen production rate was near zero with no cracking products detected, indicating that the CH bond breaking capacity of δ-MnO2 was weak (see Fig. 3b and 3c). After adding Ru, the hydrogen and CO were detected, which indicated the enhanced CH bond breaking capacity. Moreover, the H2 and CO producing rates on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can even reach 1100 ml/min/gRu and 900 ml/min/gRu, which is faster than those on Ru1/δ-MnO2. This result indicated that the CH bond-breaking ability of Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 was much stronger than Ru1/δ-MnO2. To explain the reason leading to enhanced CH bond breaking capacities over Rux/δ-MnO2, the catalysts were further characterized using XRD, SEM and XPS. Fig. 4 shows the XRD pattern of Rux/δ-MnO2. As shown in Fig. 4a, δ-MnO2 shows the typical diffraction peaks of δ-MnO2 at 2θ=12.6°, 2θ=25.1°and 2θ=37.3° [26–29]. After the addition of Ru, the typical diffraction peaks of δ-MnO2 remained, while the main diffraction peaks at 2θ=12.6° and 2θ=25.1° shift to a high angle (see Fig. 4b). This result indicated the strong interaction occurred between Ru species and δ-MnO2. With the increase of Ru loading to 1wt%, these diffraction peaks shift to the highest angle at 2θ=12.9° and 2θ=25.3° on Ru1/δ-MnO2, which indicated the enhanced interaction. While continuing to increase the Ru loading to 2 wt%, these diffraction peaks shifted to a lower angle at 2θ=12.7° and 2θ=25.2°, which indicated that the weakened interaction between Ru species and δ-MnO2. In addition, a typical diffraction peak of RuO2 at 2θ=28.8 appeared on Ru2/δ-MnO2, which indicates that RuO2 starts to agglomerate. To verify the above results, the existing state of Ru was further characterized by the TEM technique(see Fig. 5 ). The results showed that no significant RuO2 particles were observed on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru0.5/δ-MnO2 catalysts, which indicates that the Ru is uniformly dispersed as clusters or single atoms. When the loading of Ru was 1 wt%, the nanoparticles of RuO2 started to appear with relatively uniform dispersion. Continuing to increase the loading of Ru to 2 wt%, the RuO2 nanoparticles on the Ru2/δ-MnO2 catalyst started to grow and agglomerate, which is consistent with the XRD results. Meanwhile, the H2-TPR spectra show that a main peak at 327 °C and a shoulder peak at 278 °C are present on δ-MnO2 (see Fig. 6 a). While, after the addition of Ru, the above two peaks both shifted to lower temperatures with the peak at 278 °C becoming the main peak and that at 327 °C becoming the shoulder peak. These results indicated the enhanced interaction between RuOx and δ-MnO2 [ 30]. As the Ru content increased to 1wt%, the peak at 278 °C and 327 °C shifted to lower temperatures at 229 °C and 279 °C, respectively. While as the loading of Ru continue to increase to 2 wt%, those peaks moved toward high temperatures at 245 °C and 291 °C. To deeply understand the changes in the reduction peaks of the Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts, an enlarged view of the region (100–200 °C) has been analyzed (see Fig. 6b). As can be seen, no reduction peaks of RuO2 have been observed on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru0.5/δ-MnO2 catalysts. While, the reduction peaks of RuO2 near 140 °C [31–33] started to appear on Ru1/δ-MnO2, and the peak becomes stronger on Ru2/δ-MnO2. These results indicated that the Ru began to aggregate to RuO2 as Ru content above 1wt%. From the above analysis, it can be concluded that as the Ru content is below 1wt%, the highly dispersed Ru species may interact strongly with δ-MnO2, leading to the reduction temperature shifting to a lower temperature. While, as the Ru content was above 1wt%, the interaction between δ-MnO2 and the aggregated RuO2 was weakened, leading to the reduction temperature shifting to a higher temperature. This result is consistent with the XRD, TEM and XPS results. The valence state of Ru was characterized by the XPS technique, and the Ru 3p spectra are shown in Fig. 7 . The binding energies near 281.9 eV and 283 eV are corresponding to Ru4+ and Ru6+, respectively [33,34]. As can be seen from Fig. 7a, the binding energies of Ru on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 was 283 eV, indicating Ru existed as Ru6+. As the Ru loading increased to 0.5wt%, a shoulder peak at about 281.9 eV appeared, indicating the appearance of Ru4+. As the Ru loading continue to increase, the peak at 281.9 eV gradually shifted to lower energy with the enhanced peak intensity, which indicated the increased proportion of Ru4+. The average oxidation state (AOS) of Ru was calculated (see Fig. 7b). The AOS value of Ru on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 was +6, which decreased to +4.74 on Ru2/δ-MnO2. The above results show that the Ru was highly dispersed as the Ru loading below 0.5wt%, and started to agglomerate into RuO2 (Ru4+) above 1wt%. This result is consistent with the TEM result. The distribution of active oxygen species and the average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn were also characterized by the XPS technique. It was reported that the lower AOS of Mn represents the more abundant oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [35,36]. Fig. 8 a shows the AOS value of Mn of δ-MnO2 was 3.52. While the AOS value of Mn was greatly enhanced on all Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts. The AOS value of Mn increase to 3.82 on Ru1/δ-MnO2 and then decrease to 3.79 on Ru2/δ-MnO2 with increasing Ru loading, indicating that the oxygen vacancies in the catalyst first decrease and then increase. The above conclusion was then verified by XPS O 1 s spectra(see Fig. 8b). The O 1 s binding energy at 527–535 eV can be separated into three peaks, corresponding to lattice oxygen, active oxygen species, and water or oxygen adsorbed on the surface, at 530, 531.5, and 533 eV, respectively [37,38]. The results showed that the active oxygen species first decreased and then increased with increasing Ru loading. Oxidation capacity of Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts The oxidation capacity of the catalysts was characterized by the O2-TPD technique. Fig. 9 shows the O2-TPD spectra of the catalysts. The δ-MnO2 shows O2 desorption peaks in three regions at 100–200 °C, 200–450 °C and 650–800 °C (see Fig. 9a). The peaks at 200–450 °C and 650–800 °C regions are attributed to the desorption of active oxygen species (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olatt) [39,40], respectively. And oxygen desorption in the region of 100–200 °C is accompanied by the production of water (see Fig. 9b), indicating that this oxygen species(O OH) is generated by hydroxyl decomposition (2-OH→H2O+ O OH). The desorption temperature and amount of O OH remained almost constant after Ru addition, which is consistent with the hydroxyl characterization by IR. However, the peak intensity of Oads. decreased for all the Ru-added catalysts. As the Oads. are derived from the activation of oxygen by oxygen vacancies, and the peak intensity are corresponding to the number of oxygen vacancies. Thus, the above phenomenon shows that the amount of oxygen vacancies is lower on the Ru-added catalysts than δ-MnO2. As the Ru content increased, the Oads. first decreased to the minimum on Ru1/δ-MnO2 and then increased on Ru2/δ-MnO2, which indicated the amount of oxygen vacancies was lowest on Ru1/δ-MnO2. The changes trend of oxygen vacancies on Rux/δ-MnO2 was consistent with the XPS results. Discussion The structure evolution of Rux/δ-MnO2 with different ru loading Combined with the XRD, TEM, XPS and H2-TPR results, it can be deduced that Ru species on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 mainly existed as single atoms or clusters exhibiting the highest Ru AOS (AOS=6) (see Fig. 10 ). And the small-sized Ru species may strongly interact with δ-MnO2 and occupy the oxygen vacancies of δ-MnO2, leading to a decreased amount of Oads.. As the Ru loading increased to 0.5 wt%, the increased amount of Ru single atoms or Ru cluster can occupy more oxygen vacancies, leading to a continued decrease of Oads.. Moreover, some of Ru single atoms may be transformed into the RuO2 sub-nano particles, leading to the decrease of Ru AOS. While, for Ru1/δ-MnO2, a few of Ru species aggraded to RuO2, leading to the Ru AOS decreasing to 4.9. While, the residual single atoms or Ru cluster on Ru1/δ-MnO2 can still occupy more oxygen vacancies, leading to the lowest Oads.. For Ru2/δ-MnO2, most of the Ru species aggregated to RuO2 nanoparticles (>10 nm), thus this catalyst showed the lowest Ru AOS (AOS=4.74). Moreover, the interaction between RuO2 nanoparticles and δ-MnO2 is weak, resulting in the release of oxygen vacancies and thus the increase of Oads.. The promoting effect of Ru on the oxidation of furfural to furoic acid Our previous study shows the activation of the aldehyde group by hydroxyl groups on δ-MnO2 and the O OH and Oads. were important for furoic synthesis [7]. While, the FTIR spectra show that the addition of Ru did not change the intensity of hydroxyl groups of δ-MnO2, but decreased the intensity of Oads.. Moreover, the probe reaction of methanol dehydrogenation showed that the addition of Ru to δ-MnO2 greatly enhanced the capacities for breaking CH bond of geminal diol intermediate. The In-situ FTIR result showed Ru greatly accelerated the conversion of furfural and geminal diol intermediate to furoic acid. Considering the last step of furoic acid synthesis is the oxidative dehydrogenation of geminal diol through breaking CH bonds, it is deduced that the promoting effect of Ru on furoic synthesis might be due to the enhanced capacities for breaking CH bond of geminal diol intermediate. The mechanism of promoting effect of Ru on furoic synthesis was showed in Fig. 11 . As the break of CH bonds of geminal diol is accelerated by Ru species, the electronic state of Ru species might influence the furfural conversion. The relationship between the Ru AOS and furfural oxidation activity was discussed. Fig. 12 depicts the results of a correlation between Ru AOS values and TOF (intrinsic activity per Ru). As can be seen, the TOF was positively linearly related to the AOS of Ru. The Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 has the highest TOF. The XPS results showed that the Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 has the highest Ru AOS, the electron-deficient Ru in Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can strongly adsorb the H atom of the geminal diol intermediate's CH bond and hasten its breakdown, leading to the highest TOF. As the Ru loading increased, the decreasing Ru AOS weakened the ability for breaking the CH of intermediate and thus led to the decreased TOF. Conclusions In summary, the addition of trace Ru can enhance the ability for breaking the CH bond of geminal diol and promote furoic acid synthesis. The content of Ru on δ-MnO2 strongly influenced the particle size of Ru species, the Ru AOS, and the Oads. on δ-MnO2 as well as the catalytic performance for furfural oxidation to furoic acid. On Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 catalyst, the Ru species was highly dispersed as a single atom or cluster, which mainly exhibited as Ru6+ and can strongly interact with δ-MnO2. The electron-deficient Ru in Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can strongly adsorb the H atom of the CH bond of geminal diol intermediate and accelerate the breakage of its CH bond, leading to the highest TOF. With the increase of Ru content, some of Ru species started to aggregate to sub-nano or nano RuO2 and the Ru AOS began to decrease, leading to a weakened ability for breaking the CH bond of intermediate and thus the decreased TOF. This study provides a new idea for the development of eco-friendly, high reaction rate and inexpensive catalysts for furfural oxidation. coredata.dc:description: δ-MnO2 exhibits excellent activity for furfural oxidation to furoic acid under base-free conditions. However, its poor CH bond breaking capacity leads to lower conversion efficiency per unit mass catalyst than noble metal. Thus, a series of Ru-modified δ-MnO2 (Rux/δ-MnO2) have been made to enhance its CH bond breaking ability. The result showed that the furfural conversion was greatly enhanced on Rux/δ-MnO2 due to the enhanced capability for breaking the CH bond. Especially for Ru0.25/δ-MnO2, whose conversion rate per unit mass was 18 times higher than δ-MnO2. The characterization results showed that the Ru species mainly existed as single atoms or clusters on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 and Ru0.5/δ-MnO2, while started to aggregate to RuO2 nanoparticles on Ru1/δ-MnO2 and Ru2/δ-MnO2. With the increase of Ru particles, the Ru's average oxidation state (AOS) decreased from +6 on Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 to +4.74 on Ru2/δ-MnO2. The Ru's TOF (intrinsic activity per Ru) was positively linearly related to the Ru's AOS. The electron-deficient Ru in Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 can strongly adsorb the H atom of the CH of geminal diol intermediate and accelerate the breakage of its CH bond. As a result, Ru in the Ru0.25/δ-MnO2 exhibited the highest TOF, which can even reach 29.85 mmolFF/mmolRu/h.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of Ru on furoic acid synthesis from furfural oxidation over Rux/δ-MnO2 catalysts
